questions.questionText: What does the solution of this equation $$-y<5+3x$$ represents?
answers: Half-plane
A line
Bounded area in $$R^2$$

questions.questionText: What does the solution of this equation $$-2x +3y -7z = 7$$ represents?
answers: 2D Euclidean plane embedded in $$R^3$$
Surface of a ball, $$S^2$$
A line in space
Half a plane
A finite measure space

questions.questionText: What does the solution of this equation represents? $$\begin{array}{lcl} x+2y-z &=& 1 \\ 2x-2y+4z &=& -2 \\ -x+0.5y-z &=& 0 \end{array} $$
answers: A point in $$R^3$$
A line in $$R3$$
A plane embedded in $$R^3$$
Empty set
A circle

questions.questionText: What does the solution of this equation represents? $$\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}{e^{-\frac{x^2}{2}} dx} =y $$
answers: $$\sqrt{2\pi}$$
A density
Undefined

questions.questionText: What are the local and global extrema of the function $$f(x)=x^3+3x^2−2x+1$$ over the interval $$[−4,2]$$?
answers: Local minimum ($$\sim 0.6966852$$) and maximum ($$\sim 9.303315$$); Global minimum (-7) and maximum (17)
A density
Undefined

questions.questionText: What does this series represent $$\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} {	\frac{(-1)^n}{(2n+1)!} x^{2n+1} }?$$?
answers: The trigonometric sine function, $$sin(x)$$
The trigonometric cosine function, $$cos(x)$$
Taylor series expansion of $$e^{x}$$
A divergent series

questions.questionText: Starting with $$x_o=3$$, complete 3 iterations of the Newton-Raphson method, $$x_{n+1}=x_n-\frac{f(x_n)}{f'(x_n)}$$, to estimate a root of $$f(x)=x^3-20$$, i.e., find a solution to this equation: $$f(x)=x^3-20=0$$.
answers: Undefined

questions.questionText: If $$A_{3\times 3}= 	\begin{pmatrix} 3 & 2 & -1 \\ 2 & -2 & 4 \\ -1 & 1/2 & -1 \end{pmatrix}$$ and $$x_{3\times 1}= \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix}$$, what is the product $$A_{3\times 3} \times x_{3\times 1}$$?
answers: The vector $$(1,-2,0)^t$$
The matrix $$\begin{pmatrix} 3 & 2 & -1 \\ -4 & 4 & -8 \\ 2 & -1 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$$
The number $$-1$$
Undefined

questions.questionText: Give examples of linear, polynomial and exponential models of an outcome (Y) in terms of some observed input (X)
answers: $$Y=3X+5$$ (Linear), $$Y=2X^2+3X$$ (Polynomial), $$Y = 2e^{-2x}$$ (Exponential)
$$Y=2X^2+3X$$ (Linear), $$Y=3^X+3X+5$$ (Polynomial), $$Y = 2e^{-2x}$$ (Exponential)
$$Y=3^X+3X+5$$ (Linear), $$Y=2X^2+3X$$ (Polynominal), $$Y = 2e^{-2x}$$(Exponential)
$$Y=X+5$$ (Linear), $$Y=2X^4-5X$$ (Polynominal), $$Y = 2X^{-2e}$$(Exponential)

questions.questionText: What is a Graph?
answers: A graph is an ordered pair $$G = (V, E)$$ comprising a set $$V$$ of vertices or nodes or points together with a set $$E$$ of edges or arcs or lines, which are 2-element subsets of $$V$$
A graph is an object that shows relationship between nodes and vertices
Graph can be any object that conveys some informations
Graph is representation of vertices and nodes to show relationship in the data
A graph is a path that consists of vertices and nodes

questions.questionText: Suppose we draw 2 balls randomly, one at a time without replacement, from an urn containing 4 black and 3 white balls, otherwise identical. What is the probability that the second ball is black?

Suppose a patient visits a primary care clinic and is seen by a male provider not wearing a badge or other insignia. Assume that the number of primary care physicians in the US is 435,000, the number of practicing nurses is 4,500,000, and the reported gender distributions in the 2 professions (F:M ratios are 1:2 for physicians and 12:1 for nurses). Using only this information, to address the clinician appropriately, the patient is trying to figure out if he is more likely to be a doctor or a nurse (assuming these are the only options in this clinical setting). Compute and interpret the odds likelihood ratio of the clinician being a nurse

name: Formulation of Research Questions (Hypotheses), EDAs, and Confirmatory Data Analyses

questions.questionText: What is a statistic?
answers: A statistic is a function of a dataset, i.e., a single measure of some attribute of a sample
A statistic represents the probability of support or reject of the null hypothesis
A statistic calculates the confidence bounds of n estimate
A statistic is a measure used in inference to support or reject a hypothesis.
All of the above

questions.questionText: What is a p-value?
answers: The p-value (probability value) directly corresponds to a critical value of a predefined probability distribution. Under a null hypothesis $$H_o$$, the p-value corresponds to a critical value of the test statistics equal to, or more extreme, than what was actually observed.
It is the probability of rejecting/accepting Null hypothesis
It is the probability of occurrence of estimate of interest if we were to repeatedly perform the experiment
p-value is similar to test statistic used to reject or accept null hypothesis
All of the above

questions.questionText: How to interpret a confidence interval of a parameter estimate?
answers: If repeated samples were taken and the corresponding $$(1-\alpha) 100%$$-confidence intervals are computed for each sample, $$(1-\alpha) 100%$$ of the intervals would contain the parameter of interest
It is the probability that the point estimate is in the identified range/interval
After we define the confidence interval, the probability of point estimate to be in that range is 1
After we define the confidence interval, the probability of point estimate to be in that range is assumed confidence value
None of the above are correct

questions.questionText: Why is the computational complexity of the Bubble Sort algorithm is $$O(n^2)$$. This algorithm works by comparing each number in the list with the item next to it, and swaps them if needed to reorder the data from the smallest to the largest element.
answers: The inner loop complexity is $$O(n)$$ at each iteration, and the (independent) outer loop runs for $$O(n)$$ iterations, so the total computational complexity is $$O(n^2)$$

The inner loop complexity $$O(n^2)$$ at each iteration, and the outer loop runs for $$O(n)$$ iterations, so the total complexity is the ratio of the complexities of the inner and outer loops, i.e, $$O(n^2)$$
The inner loop complexity $$O(n^2)$$ at each iteration, and the outer loop runs for $$O(n^2)$$ iterations, so the total complexity is square root of inner and outer i.e., $$O(n^2)$$
The inner loop complexity $$O(n)$$ at each iteration, and the outer loop runs for $$O(n^2)$$ iterations, so the total complexity is outer divided by inner, i.e., $$O(n^2)$$
None of them is correct

questions.questionText: List two examples of programming syntax for sorting an array in R, python or Java languages.
answers: In R, sort(array), In python, array.sort()
In R, sort_values(array), In python, array.sort()
In R, sort_values(array), In python, np.sort(array)
In R, sort(array), In python, array.sort()
In R, sort(array), In python, np.array.sort()
In R, sort(array), In python, np.sort.array

questions.questionText: What is inheritance in object oriented programming?
answers: Inheritance enables new objects to take on the properties of existing objects
Inheritance enables new properties to objects in it
Inheritance restricts the new objects from taking on the properties of existing objects
Inheritance is method of sharing parent class properties to its child classes
Options 1 and 4

questions.questionText: What is binary data?
answers: Data whose unit can take on only two possible states, traditionally termed 0 and +1 in accordance with the binary numeral system
Data whose unit can take on only two possible states, traditionally termed -1 and +1 in accordance with the binary numeral system
Data whose unit can take on only two possible states, traditionally termed 0 and +1 in accordance with the ASCII numeral standards
Data whose unit can take on only two possible states, traditionally termed -1 and +1 in accordance with the ASCII numeral system
Data whose unit can take on only two possible states, traditionally termed (0 and +1) or (-1 and 1), in accordance with the binary numeral system

questions.questionText: What is a ASCII data?
answers: ASCII (American Standard Code for Information Interchange) is a term often used to mean that the data are stored in a human-readable manner, though it has a specific meaning with reference to the permitted characters allowed (i.e.,a-Z,A-Z,0-9 and few others)
Acronym for Scientific Computing, Information and Interpretation
Ask, Search, Claim, Inform, and Improvise
American Science Committee for Integrated Instruction

questions.questionText: What is Structured data?
answers: Structured data refers to highly organized information, such that inclusion in a relational interpretation of information content is seamless, and enables direct modeling and algorithmic operations
Structured data has a pre-defined schema or some sort of organization
Structured data consists of free text
Structured data is homologous to a spreadsheet

questions.questionText: What is a Unstructured data?
answers: Unstructured data (or unstructured information) is information that either does not have a pre-defined data model or is not organized in a pre-defined canonical format that easily enables storing, searching or interpretation of its context
Unstructured data are identical to linked lists
Unstructured data is a graph of information
Unstructured data represents linearly organized data streams

questions.questionText: What is a JSON data?
answers: JSON is an open-standard file format that uses human-readable text to store, navigate and transmit data objects consisting of attribute-value pairs and array data types (or any other serializable values)
Jason Borne's data framework
Java Standard for Object eNcoding
Java Single Operational Node
